newsitem.title: UK: Oversupply hits North Sea crude premiums.
newsitem.headline: Oversupply hits North Sea crude premiums.

text.p: North Sea crude oil premiums fell sharply on Tuesday afternoon on oversupply of prompt cargoes and a dearth of refiner buyers, traders said.

December Brent paper slipped 36 cents to $24.28 per barrel by 1530 GMT and the Nov/Dec spread eased by eight cents to +40 cents. Dated Brent fell nearer to parity with November paper, after a Nov 10-12 cargo traded at just two cents premium on Tuesday. Tuesday's Brent date was kept by Esso ahead of the five o'clock deadline.
"The arbitrage to the U.S. is closed, the margins are OK, but there is a buyers' strike," a trader at a major oil company said. "With low stocks the market is always going to be volatile."
Statfjord, having traded on Monday at Dated Brent +60 cents, was offered at +45 cents for loading on Nov 4-6.
Forties, which fetched +54 cents on Friday, was offered at +35 cents for 10-12 loading.
Oseberg, worth Dated +38 cents on Monday, was offered aggressively and several cargoes loading around the end of October were still available.
Bids for all these grades were well below sellers' ideas, traders said.
Urals in the Mediterranean held around dated -60/-55 cents with 2-3 large cargoes for sale. Planned pipeline maintenance of 3-4 days at Novorossiisk was thought by some to have started on Tuesday.

Nigeria's Qua Iboe was under some pressure with a cargo loading today heard still unsold but overall West African light crudes were balanced in a market where most refiners were already covered for the first half of November.
Syrian negotiations continued with best offer at dated Brent -5 cents fob Syria while lifters held off 15 cents lower. "The negotiations are very tough,' one lifter said.
